articles.headline: A Partisan Leaves; Will an Era Follow?
articles.snippet: Representative Tom DeLay, perhaps more than any other politician, embodied the intense polarization of his times.
articles.abstract: Representative Tom DeLay, perhaps more than any other politician, embodied the intense polarization of his times.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 — Representative Tom DeLay was the last man standing among the top three Republicans who took control of the House after the 1994 Republican landslide, and he leaves, in many ways, the most complex and contentious legacy from their conservative reign on Capitol Hill.

articles.headline: Massachusetts Sets Health Plan for Nearly All
articles.snippet: Combining ideas from across the political spectrum, the state would be the first to require its citizens to have insurance.
articles.abstract: Combining ideas from across the political spectrum, the state would be the first to require its citizens to have insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON, April 4 — Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to provide nearly universal health care coverage with a bill passed overwhelmingly by the legislature Tuesday that Gov. Mitt Romney says he will sign.

articles.headline: Hussein Charged With Genocide in 50,000 Deaths
articles.snippet: The charges, the largest against the Iraqi ex-president so far, stem from attacks in 1998 that destroyed 2,000 Kurdish villages.
articles.abstract: The charges, the largest against the Iraqi ex-president so far, stem from attacks in 1998 that destroyed 2,000 Kurdish villages.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 4 — The Iraqi court trying Saddam Hussein announced Tuesday that it had charged him with genocide, saying he sought to annihilate the Kurdish people in 1988, when the military killed at least 50,000 Kurdish civilians and destroyed 2,000 villages.

articles.headline: Big Gain for Rich Seen in Tax Cuts for Investments
articles.snippet: The first data to document the effect of President Bush's tax cuts for investment income show that they have significantly lowered the tax burden on the richest Americans, reducing taxes on incomes of more than $10 million by an average of about $...
articles.abstract: The first data to document the effect of President Bush's tax cuts for investment income show that they have significantly lowered the tax burden on the richest Americans, reducing taxes on incomes of more than $10 million by an average of about $500,000.     An analysis of Internal Revenue Service data by The New York Times found that the benefit of the lower taxes on investments was far more concentrated on the very wealthiest Americans than the benefits of Mr. Bush's two previous tax cuts: on wages and other noninvestment income.

articles.headline: Patchy Recovery in New Orleans
articles.snippet: Anyone looking for a potent symbol of the battered state of the economy here seven months after Hurricane Katrina might stop by the offices of Don Hutchinson, the city's economic development director. People seeking assistance from Mr. Hutchinson'...
articles.abstract: Anyone looking for a potent symbol of the battered state of the economy here seven months after Hurricane Katrina might stop by the offices of Don Hutchinson, the city's economic development director. People seeking assistance from Mr. Hutchinson's agency are greeted by a pair of revolving doors that have been sheathed in plywood and shut since shortly after the storm struck at the end of August. Visitors must enter through a side door.     There are any number of signs signaling a steady but unsure recovery in New Orleans, from a vibrant nightlife in pockets of town to census estimates that suggest that the city is repopulating at a much faster pace than predicted a few months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS - Anyone looking for a potent symbol of the battered state of the economy here seven months after Hurricane Katrina might stop by the offices of Don Hutchinson, the city's economic development director. People seeking assistance from Mr. Hutchinson's agency are greeted by a pair of revolving doors that have been sheathed in plywood and shut since shortly after the storm struck at the end of August. Visitors must enter through a side door.

articles.headline: Massachusetts Sets Health Plan for Nearly All
articles.snippet: Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to provide nearly universal health care coverage with a bill passed overwhelmingly by the legislature Tuesday that Gov. Mitt Romney says he will sign.     The bill does what health experts say no o...
articles.abstract: Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to provide nearly universal health care coverage with a bill passed overwhelmingly by the legislature Tuesday that Gov. Mitt Romney says he will sign.     The bill does what health experts say no other state has been able to do: provide a mechanism for all of its citizens to obtain health insurance. It accomplishes that in a way that experts say combines methods and proposals from across the political spectrum, apportioning the cost among businesses, individuals and the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON, April 4 - Massachusetts is poised to become the first state to provide nearly universal health care coverage with a bill passed overwhelmingly by the legislature Tuesday that Gov. Mitt Romney says he will sign.

articles.headline: 6,000 Pilots at Delta Air Vote to Strike
articles.snippet: The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday. The panel is expect...
articles.abstract: The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday. The panel is expected to issue a ruling by April 15.     The decision by the pilots gives negotiators on both sides more than a week to narrow their differences and avoid a work stoppage that many believe would lead to a liquidation of Delta. Among the issues is the company's request for $305 million in annual pay cuts; the pilots have offered $140 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nearly 6,000 pilots at Delta Air Lines, proving resistant to a second round of concessions, voted overwhelmingly to approve a strike should their contract be voided by an arbitration panel, the pilots' union said yesterday. The panel is expected to issue a ruling by April 15.
articles.byline: By Jeff Bailey and Christopher Elliott

articles.headline: About the Tables
articles.snippet: The Times is changing its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.      As part of a continuing effort to integrate The Times and its Web ve...
articles.abstract: The Times is changing its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.      As part of a continuing effort to integrate The Times and its Web version, online readers will be able to choose from an array of new functions, including a host of interactive graphics. Today's Sector Snapshot chart can be found on Page C10.     Readers will also be able to receive closing prices of their stocks and mutual funds by e-mail and will be able to receive midday alerts about sharp price shifts or business news that affects them.      Full financial tables will continue to appear in the Sunday newspaper, covering stocks, bonds, mutual funds and foreign markets.     Comments about the changes may be e-mailed to tables@nytimes.com or telephoned to (212) 556-3715.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times is changing its daily financial tables, replacing the six existing pages with two pages of analytical tools and summary information on the markets and the economy.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Offers Aid to Rivals
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart Stores, whose all-in-one retailing model has forced scores of competitors to close their doors over the last 40 years, is turning to an unusual business plan: helping its rivals.      The giant discount retailer, under increasing assault ...
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart Stores, whose all-in-one retailing model has forced scores of competitors to close their doors over the last 40 years, is turning to an unusual business plan: helping its rivals.      The giant discount retailer, under increasing assault by critics, announced a wide-ranging effort yesterday to support small businesses near its new urban stores, including the hardware stores, dress shops and bakeries with which it competes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wal-Mart Stores, whose all-in-one retailing model has forced scores of competitors to close their doors over the last 40 years, is turning to an unusual business plan: helping its rivals.

articles.headline: Software Out There
articles.snippet: Smaller companies are producing pioneering software and Web-based services that can be delivered directly to PCs, or even to cellphones, and larger companies are taking note of trend; smaller companies are also beginning to share their technology ...
articles.abstract: Smaller companies are producing pioneering software and Web-based services that can be delivered directly to PCs, or even to cellphones, and larger companies are taking note of trend; smaller companies are also beginning to share their technology with outside programmers to leverage their competitive positions, making it possible for developers to add powerful abilities to core products and create new ones from scratch; idea of modular software, where standard components can be easily linked together, has generally been limited by corporate strategies that have held customers and other programmers hostage to proprietary systems; those limitations are rapidly easing, mostly because of open-source software movement, which promotes making information available to everyone; shift toward sharing has touched off spate of software design and start-up activity not seen since dot-com frenzy; drawing (L)

articles.headline: The Economics of Henry Ford May Be Passé
articles.snippet: HENRY FORD was 50 years old, and not all that different from a lot of other successful businessmen, when he summoned the Detroit press corps to his company's offices on Jan. 5, 1914. What he did that day made him a household name.     Mr. Ford ann...
articles.abstract: HENRY FORD was 50 years old, and not all that different from a lot of other successful businessmen, when he summoned the Detroit press corps to his company's offices on Jan. 5, 1914. What he did that day made him a household name.     Mr. Ford announced that he was doubling the pay of thousands of his employees, to at least $5 a day. With his company selling Model T's as fast as it could make them, his workers deserved to share in the profits, he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: HENRY FORD was 50 years old, and not all that different from a lot of other successful businessmen, when he summoned the Detroit press corps to his company's offices on Jan. 5, 1914. What he did that day made him a household name.

articles.headline: Syria Imposing Stronger Curbs on Opposition
articles.snippet: Just months ago, under intense international pressure to ease its stranglehold on neighboring Lebanon, the Syrian government was talking about ending the ruling Baath Party's grip on Syrian power and paving the way for a multiparty system.     But...
articles.abstract: Just months ago, under intense international pressure to ease its stranglehold on neighboring Lebanon, the Syrian government was talking about ending the ruling Baath Party's grip on Syrian power and paving the way for a multiparty system.     But things have moved in the opposite direction. Syrian officials are aggressively silencing domestic political opposition while accommodating religious conservatives to shore up support across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria, April 4 - Just months ago, under intense international pressure to ease its stranglehold on neighboring Lebanon, the Syrian government was talking about ending the ruling Baath Party's grip on Syrian power and paving the way for a multiparty system.

articles.headline: At the Enron Trial, Skilling Then vs. Skilling Now
articles.snippet: As Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, moves from the defense table to the witness stand as soon as today, he will have to be prepared to confront his own past testimony.     At his trial in Houston, Mr. Skilling will be bound by ...
articles.abstract: As Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, moves from the defense table to the witness stand as soon as today, he will have to be prepared to confront his own past testimony.     At his trial in Houston, Mr. Skilling will be bound by the very words he spoke under oath in secret testimony given more than four years ago, at a time when the Enron criminal investigation had not yet begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Jeffrey K. Skilling, Enron's former chief executive, moves from the defense table to the witness stand as soon as today, he will have to be prepared to confront his own past testimony.
articles.byline: By Kurt Eichenwald and Alexei Barrionuevo

articles.headline: A Partisan Leaves; Will an Era Follow?
articles.snippet: Representative Tom DeLay was the last man standing among the top three Republicans who took control of the House after the 1994 Republican landslide, and he leaves, in many ways, the most complex and contentious legacy from their conservative reig...
articles.abstract: Representative Tom DeLay was the last man standing among the top three Republicans who took control of the House after the 1994 Republican landslide, and he leaves, in many ways, the most complex and contentious legacy from their conservative reign on Capitol Hill.     Mr. DeLay, who stepped down as majority leader last fall after being indicted in Texas, told his constituents on Tuesday that he would not run for re-election and would resign from Congress in the next few months.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 - Representative Tom DeLay was the last man standing among the top three Republicans who took control of the House after the 1994 Republican landslide, and he leaves, in many ways, the most complex and contentious legacy from their conservative reign on Capitol Hill.

articles.headline: Hussein Charged With Genocide in 50,000 Deaths
articles.snippet: The Iraqi court trying Saddam Hussein announced Tuesday that it had charged him with genocide, saying he sought to annihilate the Kurdish people in 1988, when the military killed at least 50,000 Kurdish civilians and destroyed 2,000 villages.     ...
articles.abstract: The Iraqi court trying Saddam Hussein announced Tuesday that it had charged him with genocide, saying he sought to annihilate the Kurdish people in 1988, when the military killed at least 50,000 Kurdish civilians and destroyed 2,000 villages.      The case is the first against Mr. Hussein to address the large-scale human rights violations committed during his decades in power, the same acts the Bush administration has publicized in explaining the American invasion of Iraq. Six other defendants also face charges. Mr. Hussein is already being tried for the torture and killings of 148 men and boys in the Shiite village of Dujail.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 4 - The Iraqi court trying Saddam Hussein announced Tuesday that it had charged him with genocide, saying he sought to annihilate the Kurdish people in 1988, when the military killed at least 50,000 Kurdish civilians and destroyed 2,000 villages.

articles.headline: Yes, the New Macintosh and Windows Can Be Friends
articles.snippet: David Pogue column on integration of Windows XP operating system with Apple Macintosh; flexibility is made possible by Intel chip that is powering many Macintosh models and will power all of them by end of year; innovation came about through conte...
articles.abstract: David Pogue column on integration of Windows XP operating system with Apple Macintosh; flexibility is made possible by Intel chip that is powering many Macintosh models and will power all of them by end of year; innovation came about through contest won by San Francisco-area programmer Jesus Lopez; drawing (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU should see my new Windows XP computer. It's so cool looking. It's a compact, silent, rounded six-inch slab, only two inches tall. Its sidewalls are brushed aluminum, and the top is white acrylic -- with a big gray Apple logo in the middle.
